#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Tell if a Dog Is Microchipped
#Text=Microchips placed in dogs are small passive radio emitters about the size of a grain of rice that are injected under the skin above the shoulder blades .

#Text=Each microchip has a unique number , and that number is registered on an official central database along with a description of that dog , the owner 's name , address , and contact phone numbers .
#Text=When a scanner is passed over the microchip , that unique number is picked up and displayed on the scanner .
#Text=Knowing if a dog has a microchip is especially helpful if you find a stray dog and need to trace the owner .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Looking For a Microchip
#Text=Look for a tag on the dog 's collar .
#Text=If the dog is wearing a collar take a look to see if it has a specific tag that says the dog is microchipped .
#Text=Microchips are made by different manufacturers , and these companies usually issue a metal tags to place on the dog 's collar to alert interested parties that the dog is chipped .

#Text=The tag is supplied in part to let anyone that finds a dog know that it is chipped in order to scan them but it is also a visual deterrent to potential thieves thinking of stealing the dog , since the dog has permanent ID as belonging to someone else .
#Text=If the dog does not have an official ID tag on their collar , look for a bespoke collar tag bearing wording such as " I am microchipped " or " microchipped . "

column1: #Text=Know that this is not the same as a tag engraved with the dog 's name and phone number .
#Text=The purpose of this tag is purely to alert the finder that the dog is chipped and should be scanned .
#Text=This type of tag usually does not carry personal details .
#Text=Feel for the microchip .
#Text=If the dog has lost their collar or there is no tag on the collar , try gently feeling for the presence of the microchip .
#Text=The microchip is encased in a perspex coat that is the size and shape of a grain of rice .
#Text=Microchips are injected under the skin in the loose skin of the neck at the centerline between the shoulder blades .
#Text=Therefore this is the ideal place to start feeling .
#Text=Run your fingertips over the skin between the shoulder blades and neck .
#Text=Apply gentle pressure to see if you can detect a firm rice-grain sized object just under the skin .
#Text=Microchips do bed in , which means they can migrate slightly from the original implant site .

#Text=To reduce the chance of missing a microchip , work in a methodical manner working up and down between shoulder and head and then left to right working side to side from the shoulders up the neck until every inch is covered .
#Text=This is not a foolproof method .
#Text=If you ca n't feel a chip it does not mean the dog is definitely not chipped because the chip may be present but have shifted location or is embedded too deeply to feel .
#Text=Get a definitive answer by getting the dog scanned .
#Text=Even if the dog does n't have a tag that says it has a chip and you do n't feel one , it 's best to scan the dog to find out .
#Text=It is worth scanning for a microchip if you are trying to get the contact details of a lost dog 's owner .
#Text=X-ray the dog .
#Text=Microchips show up on x-ray .

#Text=While this is not routinely used as a method to check if a chip is present , in cases where a chip was implanted and has stopped working , taking a radiograph of the dog is a quick and easy way to check the chip is still in place but not working .
#Text=Scanning For a Microchip
#Text=Check the scanner .
#Text=First , the operator needs to check that the scanner is working by pressing the ' on ' button and passing the sensor over a test chip .
#Text=If the scanner bleeps and displays a number it is working .
#Text=If the batteries are dead the display will either remain blank or display a message " low battery . "
#Text=If the scanner is working but has not scanned a microchip after a set period of time
#Text=it displays the message " no chip found . "
#Text=Scan the dog 's shoulders .
#Text=Turn on the scanner and hold it one inch above the skin .
#Text=Move the scanner in up and down sweeps from the shoulder to neck and then from side to side .
#Text=When the scanner activates , make a note of the number .
#Text=Check other places on the dog 's body .
#Text=If no chip is found with a methodical scanning pattern over the shoulders , do n't give up .
#Text=Pass the scanner over the remainder of the body .
#Text=This includes under the sternum and around the armpits , just in case it has migrated to an unusual location .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Microchip scanning can be done at most veterinary clinics .
#Text=If you have found a stray dog , take it to a local veterinarian to get scanned .
#Text=Microchips are also a great way of proving ownership .
#Text=Your veterinarian or an animal welfare officer can implant the chip and put your information into the database .
#Text=This process means the pet is officially registered with your details .
#Text=The database then issues the owner a certificate , which has a copy of the details and a password .
#Text=Thus , the only person capable of changing the registered details is the owner in possession of a valid password .
#Text=This means that if your dog is stolen and then spotted by the police , the results of scanning the microchip can prove that you own that animal .
#Text=Quick Summary
